subNodes.conversationText: root
My patience with you champions will only extend so far.
Calm down. When we have something, we will bring gifts and tidings back to you.
Likewise, Lady Minstrel.
A woman from Hearkenwold asked us to deliver this poem, for your consideration as a new song.
I greet you again, brave adventurers.
Hello, Lady Madrigal. I am afraid we must be on our way.
Here are your instruments. Use them in good health.
Rorn and his band of goblins have left their camp. I do not think they are coming back.

You see! I told you this was just a ploy, accusing me of not having ownership of those musical instruments! I am the bard, he is the brigand... it is not that complicated. Now you must track him down and find each item for us.
Yes, you have my word, we will return with the instruments.
I must? Lady, I do not have time for chasing wild geese. Fare well.
A woman from Hearkenwold asked us to deliver this poem, for your consideration as a new song.
We met a man in Khyn. I believe those instruments were his.
I see. And you are certain these particular items... a lyre, a flute and a fiddle, came from him? It would rather seem our misfortune after your hard-fought return to us, only to lose them again.
Continue
Good day, Madam. Those instruments you hold are part of a very exquisite collection. I run a musical stand in Khyn, and I am the owner of these items. I am Franz Maestro.
Continue
But of course you are.
Lady Madgrial, now is your chance to pay the man and own your instruments honestly.
How... how much will they cost us?
Continue
One thousand pieces of gold. Your mistress knows the craftsmanship is remarkable. And the tone produced, pitch perfect.
Continue

Indeed. Then here are your instruments. We are not prepared to pay that amount. Instead, Tremin and I will have to look to move to another location. It seems we cannot afford these environs. Come along, Tremin.
Well I'm glad this all worked out.
This is all very amusing.
How... how much will they cost us?
I greet you again, wanderers from the Castle.
At least you are still alive and doing well. Good day.
We have confronted this Rorn the Black...
Excellent! Then you have recovered our musical instruments. I am most impressed. You are truly a credit to the Crown.
We do not have the instruments with us.
Why... whatever happened?
Rorn told us the musical instruments are not yours.

And you believed him? He is playing you for a fool! The half-goblin is a brigand, a traitorous and venomed scullian. I would not be surprised if he has absconded already with our most prized possessions.
He seemed sincere, in a brutish sort of way, about not wanting a fight.

Ha ha, that is just like Rorn the Black. A coward at heart. Although he threatened us with harm if we did not make continued payments after the sale of these items, in the end, he and his goons merely took them from us.
So it's extortion, then. That is a different matter.
He used an implied threat of force to secure ongoing payments from you.
We wanted to talk to you first.

Talk? I asked you to bring back our stolen instruments from that ruffian! It was a simple request. And while I can imagine Rorn might not part with such valuables easily, that was for you to convince him otherwise. Preferably, with violence. That is not our sort of thing.
Continue.
My Lady, perhaps we should come clean and be forthright about these events.
Rorn mentioned that the instruments actually belong to him.

And you believed him? He is playing you for a fool! The half-goblin is a brigand, a traitorous and venomed scullian. I would not be surprised if he has absconded already with our most prized possessions.
Continue.
My Lady, perhaps we should come clean and be forthright about these events.
Continue.

Oh, Tremin, don't be a such a knave. Very well! The truth is, we did purchase those instruments, honestly... although perhaps below the value of the market. We cannot be sure of the source whence Rorn procured them. But then that oaf came back and demanded interest... further payments in order for us to keep the instruments.
Continue.
And when we could no longer make the payments, Rorn the Black took them from us. Repossessed, he said.
So it's extortion, then. That is a different matter.

Quite so. Listen, I understand if there are those from the Castle who would consider us no better than traveling gypsies. We truly did purchase our instruments with coin. However, this Rorn was the only seller around. Unfortunately, the brute was not satisfied with our agreed upon terms.
Now that we have some clarity on the matter, we will try to find a reasonable solution. Farewell.
Here are your instruments. Use them in good health.
He used an implied threat of force to secure ongoing payments from you.

More or less. His band of thugs is certainly intimidating before a couple of unarmed bards. But in the end, he was content to take back the musical instruments, and there was nothing we could do to stop him. I dare say, you would be doing much to spare other unfortunate individuals a similar fate, if you could deal with Rorn the Black.
Now that we have some clarity on the matter, we will try to find a reasonable solution. Farewell.
Here are your instruments. Use them in good health.
Here are your instruments. Use them in good health.
Thank you ever so much. Aside from her voice, these instruments are not only a bard's livelihood, but the emblem of our profession. Returning them to Tremin and I is greatly appreciated.
I believe you owe us a song.
Fair enough,  a deal's a deal. My Lady will now reward you with a treasure more valuable than rubies and diamonds...
Continue.
Tremin, hush. Mind the rhythm and counterpoint.
Continue.

Just beguiler,


Kindest love yet only chastest,


Royal in thy smooth denials,


Frowning or demurely smiling,


Still my pure delight.
Continue.

Let me view thee

With thoughts and with eyes affected,

And if then the flames do murmur,

Quench them with thy virtue, charm them

With thy stormy brows.
Continue.

Heaven so cheerful

Laughs not ever; hoary winter

Knows his season, even the freshest

Summer morns from angry thunder

Yet not still secure.
That was lovely, Lady Madrigal. Fare well.
You know those instruments were probably stolen from their original owner.

Yes, I understand. Rorn is crook who operates from a black market. I should not have been dealing with him, but at the time, his prices were the only ones we could afford. I will tell you what... if you can locate the rightful owner of these pieces, then I will offer to give them back.
Continue.
My Lady, look... there is an engraved fancy rune for the letter M on this lyre.
Continue.

Tremin, sometimes you heed too much attention to fine details for your own good. Yes, I noticed that signature character. I thought it was perfect for Lady Madrigal. Nevertheless, I suppose it is something to go on if our friends from the Castle are intent on finding the true owner.
Enjoy the instruments for now. Fare well.
A woman from Hearkenwold asked us to deliver this poem, for your consideration as a new song.
I greet you again, wanderers from the Castle.
At least you are still alive and doing well. Good day.
Here are your instruments. Use them in good health.
A woman from Hearkenwold asked us to deliver this poem, for your consideration as a new song.
Is that so? Interesting, I shall read it over and determine if this poem is worthy to put a tune to the words.
Most kind of you, and I'm sure Abigail will appreciate it.
Hello, fellow wanderers! How fare you this day? I am Lady Madrigal. Perhaps I can delight you with a song?
As if that is even your real name.

You are suspicious of everyone, arent you. Well of course I have chosen a show name for entertainment purposes, as a traveling bard. All the same, the value of using an alias to keep unwanted contacts at a distance is not something to be taken lightly.
Continue.
My Lady, you don't suppose they work for Rorn, do you?
Continue.
Hush, Tremin. These do not look like the type of individuals Rorn would employ. Still, that gives me an idea. I wonder if they might be able to help us.
I would be happy to help, if I can.

Now that is very generous of you. I must warn you, we do not have much to give in way of a reward. Only our gratitude and perhaps a free song whenever you like. That is, if you can find our musical instruments, stolen by the notorious bandit, Rorn the Black.
I understand. We will search out this thief and bring back your property.
My heart flutters with joy. Yes, if you could find the means to recover our items, that would be incredibly fantastic. I wish you good fortune, and be careful.
Farewell, Lady Madrigal.
Who is Rorn the Black?

An unsavory character, half goblin, I believe. That is how he came to be known as Rorn the Black. His blood must be black like a goblin's. And now he has taken our instruments. Quite a tragic development, actually.
Who is Rorn?

An unsavory character, half goblin, I believe. That is how he came to be known as Rorn the Black. His blood must be black like a goblin's. And now he has taken our instruments. Quite a tragic development, actually.
Say no more. We will recover your property and return to you.
I am not interested in getting involved in this dispute.
Who is Tremin?

Oh, Tremin here? Do not mind him. He is an aspiring young bard performing in my service. I'm sure you can appreciate that. There are some who swear their loyalty to the Crown. Others to the Art of Magic. And then there are those of us, to whom Music is our Master.
Continue.
Unfortunately, a bandit has stolen all our instruments.
Say no more. We will recover your property and return to you.
I am not interested in getting involved in this dispute.
It seems unsafe to be wandering beyond the reach of the Castle.

Ha ha, I could say the same of you, it would seem. Oh, but are you from Castle Hearkenwold? I don't mean to offend, however sometimes safety is not such a sure thing behind those walls. Nor is it always desirable. Then again, it is true that there are dangers out in the world.
Continue.

I hesitate to trouble you with this information. Perhaps it is for your own good, as well as ours. You see, there is a notorious bandit named Rorn the Black roaming the wood. He has stolen our musical instruments.
Say no more. We will recover your property and return to you.
Then I must wish you the best of fortune. Now please understand, that we do not have much to offer in way of a reward. But surely such noble service will not go unnoticed or unappreciated.
Farewell, Lady Madrigal.
I am not interested in getting involved in this dispute.
I understand. If you should change your mind, you will find us here. Without our instruments.
Farewell, Lady Madrigal.
Sure, a song would be perfect to brighten our mood.
How splendid! I must inform you our singing will have to be in polyphonic a cappella form, that is, without any instrumentation. You see, we have had some recent misfortune with a notorious bandit.
Continue.
My Lady, you don't suppose they work for Rorn, do you?
